Award.AwardTitle: SHINE: Estimating Source Locations of Interplanetary Type II Radio Bursts with Direction Finding Technique
Award.AbstractNarration:
The main goal of this 3-year SHINE project is to study the locations of the type II radio bursts at frequencies around and below 1 MHz by utilizing measurements from the Wind/WAVES and STEREO/WAVES radio instruments. The obtained radio source locations will be compared with the white-light images of Coronal Mass Ejections (CMEs) taken by the SOHO/LASCO and STEREO/SECCHI coronagraphs and heliospheric imagers. This research project will shed more light on the origin of the type II radio emissions during CME events and related shock waves. Furthermore, the project team aims to test the validity of various theoretical models of the type II radio bursts.

This research project contributes to broader societal activities, such as advancing the participation of women in science and improving the scientific literacy of the general public. The project team will present the results of this research project at national scientific meetings and will publish them in peer-reviewed scientific journals. In addition, the team will setup and maintain a website, where all relevant data for each analyzed radio event will be made available to the general public. The research and EPO agenda of this SHINE project supports the Strategic Goals of the AGS Division in discovery, learning, diversity, and interdisciplinary research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Goals of the project are to determine the locations of the radio sources of type II bursts associated with fast coronal mass ejection (CME) -driven shocks by using direction finding techniques, including the source location of the enhanced type II radio emission associated with interacting CMEs.

In the most recent study we investigated the 2012 July 6 solar eruption, which was associated with an intense X1.1 solar flare and a fast halo coronal mass ejection (CME), type III and type II radio bursts. There were actually two separate type II radio bursts observed. The higher-frequency, metric-to-decametric type II radio burst extended down to ∼5 MHz. At the same time, a slowly drifting feature with a fundamental-harmonic structure was observed by radio receivers on the Wind and STEREO spacecraft around and below 1 MHz. The radio direction finding analysis, which can determine the arrival direction of radio waves, indicates that the radio source of this lower-frequency interplanetary (IP) type II radio burst was located near the nose and possibly towards the southern flank of the CME-driven shock. Because the metric type II burst occurred at the higher frequency, and we know that the type II emission frequency is proportional to the ambient plasma density, the radio source of the metric type II burst must have been closer to the Sun, where the plasma density is higher, than the radio source of the IP type II burst. Therefore, our results provide an independent confirmation of previous suggestions that when the metric and IP type II bursts are overlapping in time, the lower-frequency IP type II radio burst originates near the shock nose, whereas the source of the higher-frequency metric type II burst is closer to the Sun in the shock flank region. These results also support the idea that the coronal and IP type II bursts are produced by the same CME-driven shock.
